thread.title: ASIC to recover investigation costs

title: ASIC to recover investigation costs
text:
Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 8:31 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets closed ASIC to recover investigation costs AAP â€“ 41 minutes ago View Photo 

The corporate watchdog plans to recover its investigation costs after spending large sums on prosecutions and civil proceedings. 
The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) said it had rarely recovered its investigation expenses and costs, but it would now seek to recover the money from parties that had caused them to be incurred. 
ASIC Commissioner John Price said the decision had been made for reasons of fairness and equity rather than in response to budget constraints or a particular legal case. 
"There wasn't any particular investigation that triggered this," Mr Price told reporters in Perth on Wednesday. 
"What really triggered this was the current commission thinks it's an important principle that the people who drive the need for regulation and the cost of regulation actually pay for that. 
"It's not about funding." 
Mr Price added that ASIC had not made projections about the amount of money that could be recovered. 
ASIC hopes the use of the legal provisions will speed up investigations and court action, resulting in savings for all parties. 
The commission will use current laws to apply to the recovery of staff salaries, travel expenses, expert fees and legal fees to investigations starting from Wednesday and some investigations which commenced before that date. 
It will also use its discretion not to pursue costs if those under investigation comply with its inquiries. 
Meanwhile, ASIC identified trends which it is examining closely in the mining industry in Western Australia.
